billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO CRIME VICTIMS, CRIME AND CORRECTION

title: Requires contractors to give immediate written notice to the crime victims board regarding payments of profit of a crime
summary: Requires contractors to give immediate written notice to the crime victims board regarding payments of profit of a crime and imposes civil liability for the failure to comply therewith.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2335

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the executive law, in relation to payments received as profit
for a crime

PURPOSE:
The purpose of this bill is to encourage persons contracting with
convicted criminals to contact the crime victims Board

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
The bill establishes a civil penalty up to the full amount of a
contract, except that if the consideration offered or contracted is
$25,000 or more the fine would be $25,000 plus up to 25% of the
contract, for failure to give written notice to the Crime Victims
Board when entering into a contract with convicted criminals and the
payment or obligation to pay could be construed as "profits from a
crime". Any fine collected as a result of a violation will be held in
escrow for the potential benefits of the victim prior to it be it
being deposited according to procedures stipulated in section 7 (b)
(i). This bill would establish a civil penalty in the Executive Law.

JUSTIFICATION:
Section 632-a.2(a) of the Executive Law requires that any person,
firm, corporation, partnership, association or other legal entity
which knowingly contracts for par, or agrees to pay, any profit from
a crime to a person charged with or convicted of that crime should
give written notice to the Crime Victims Board of the payment, or
obligation to pay, as soon as is practicable after discovery that
intended payment is a profit of the crime. The statute, however, does
not penalize companies which do not notify the Board. Recently, Time
Warner paid $55,000 to Laurie Kellog, who is serving twenty-five
years to life for her role in the 1991 murder of her husband, for the
use of her story as the basis for a television movie. A lawsuit has
now been filed by the State on behalf of the murder victim Bruce
Kellog's family. While it's rare that criminals are paid
large amounts of money for the rights to their story, this
notification to the Crime Victims Board should be ensured.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
03/07/07 REFERRED TO CRIME VICTIMS, CRIME AND CORRECTION
01/09/08 REFERRED TO CRIME VICTIMS, CRIME AND CORRECTION
06/01/09 REPORTED AND COMMITTED TO CODES
05/21/10 AMEND AND RECOMMIT TO CRIME VICTIMS, CRIME AND CORRECTION

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
There may be some increased revenue to the State as a result of the
fines imposed under this legislation.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

This act shall take effect immediately.
